title: Experimental inoculation of coral recruits with marine bacteria indicates scope for microbiome manipulation in Acropora tenuis and Platygyra daedalea
abstract: P r o v i s i o n a l Experimental inoculation of coral recruits with marine bacteria 1 indicates scope for microbiome manipulation in Acropora tenuis and 2

abstract.text: P r o v i s i o n a l Experimental inoculation of coral recruits with marine bacteria 1 indicates scope for microbiome manipulation in Acropora tenuis and 2

body_text.text: Scleractinian corals are responsible for building the three-dimensional structure of coral reefs 54 through the deposition of their calcium carbonate skeletons, thereby providing habitat for over a 55 quarter of all marine species (Spadling et al. 2001) . Most scleractinian corals are colonial 56 organisms, comprised of large numbers of interconnected polyps. Having persisted for over 200 inoculation of amphibian hosts holds promise to prevent the extinction of vulnerable populations.

Similar to plants and other animals, exposing corals to certain microbial communities may trigger a 123 beneficial shift in the symbiosis and render the holobiont more resilient to external pressures.

Although the notion of exogenously adding microbes to corals in a probiotic approach was (Apprill et al. 2009; Damjanovic et al. 2017) . Further, the bacterial communities associated 143 with early coral life stages tend to be more dynamic as compared to the associations harbored by 144 adults (Littman et al. 2009a; Lema et al. 2014; Epstein et al. 2019a) .

The objective of the present study was firstly to gain more insights into how associations between 147 young corals and bacteria can be manipulated by targeted bacterial inoculations, and secondly, to

The inoculation cocktail was made from pure cultures of bacteria belonging to the genera 192 Acinetobacter, Bacterioplanes, Marinobacter, Paracoccus, Pseudoalteromonas, Pseudovibrio, and 193 Vibrio, which had been previously isolated from marine invertebrates and stored as frozen stocks 194 (Table 1) . As the goal of the present study consisted in assessing the potential of manipulating the 195 microbiome of juvenile corals, the bacteria used were not selected for putative beneficial properties.
body_text.section: P r o v i s i o n a l

body_text.text: Rather, we aimed to test to what extent the bacteria harbored by young recruits could be influenced 197 by targeted inoculation as further support for the proof-of-concept of coral microbiome 198 manipulation. The use of isolates from various marine organisms provides information about a 199 range of bacterial sources that could be taken up by given coral species and hence how flexible 200 these symbiotic partnerships are.

(BD™, USA) and grown overnight in a shaking incubator at 28 o C. Liquid cultures were re-streaked 227 onto minimal marine agar; the procedure was repeated until pure cultures were obtained, which 228 were stored at -80°C in 20% glycerol.

Vibrio harveyi was purchased from the Leibniz Institute DSMZ -German Collection of Inoculation of coral recruits with bacteria and sampling manually wearing different pairs of ethanol-sterilized gloves between each replicate. On the first 262 day of bacterial inoculation, recruits from all tanks were also exposed to a pure culture of naturally associates with C. goreaui (Abrego et al. 2009) .

Thirty-six hours after the recruits had been placed back in the flow-through 60 L tanks following rRNA gene, ~30 polyps for each recruit replicate sample were pooled for DNA extraction (i.e. both 293 treatments provided six replicates of ~30 polyps each), while 60 µL were used for the C. goreaui 294 culture and each bacterial inoculum. Samples were placed in 1.5 mL sterile microcentrifuge tubes 295 containing 250 µL of extraction buffer (100 mM Tris pH 9.0, 100 mM EDTA, 1% SDS, 100 mM beaten at 4 m/s for 20 sec and incubated at 55°C for 2 h, followed by 65°C for 15 min. After this step, 62.5 µL of KOAc at 5 M were pipetted into the tubes and incubated on ice for 30 min. After spinning the tubes at 25,000g for 15 min at room temperature, the supernatant was transferred into new 1.5 mL sterile microcentrifuge tubes and 0.8 vol. isopropanol was added to precipitate DNA.
The solutions were left at room temperature for 15 min and centrifuged again at 25,000g for 15 min.
centrifuged at 25,000g for 3 min, air-dried and resuspended overnight in 25 µL MilliQ water.

The same DNA suspensions were used to amplify the 16S rRNA gene and ITS2 marker. Variable 308 regions V5 to V6 of the 16S rRNA gene were amplified using the forward primer 784F San Diego, CA, USA). The PCRs were conducted in 10 µL triplicates using the AmpliTaq Gold 319 360 Master Mix and 0.4 µM of each primer. The amplification cycles were: 95°C for 10 min; 30 320 cycles each at 95°C for 30 sec, 57°C for 1 min, 72°C for 30 sec; a final extension at 72°C for 7 min.

The PCR triplicates for each template were pooled and sent to Ramaciotti Centre for Genomics 322 (UNSW, Sydney) for library preparation and sequencing on the Illumina MiSeq system with 323 2x300bp paired-end reads.

In addition to processing the samples, six blank DNA extractions and three no-template PCRs were Both the 16S rRNA gene partial sequences and ITS2 region sequences were processed using the for which the minimum overall relative abundance was lower than 10 -5 were filtered out of the 354 dataset in order to mitigate the generation of spurious sequences (Bokulich et al. 2013). To account 355 for the variability in the number of reads per sample, data counts were rarefied to an even depth, 356 corresponding to the minimum number of reads across samples.

Recruit survival rates were modeled using generalized linear models with binomial distribution, and 359 linear contrasts were used to test for differences between the treatments. Alpha diversity as a 360 measure for richness was computed using Chao and Shannon α-diversity indices (Lande 1996;  and treatments, generalized linear models with gamma distributions were fitted, and linear contrasts 363 were used to test differences in richness. Differences in community composition (β-diversity, permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA, (Anderson 2001) (Benjamini and Hochberg 1995) . In addition, we performed 371 differential pairwise abundance comparisons using unrarefied data based on generalized linear 372 models with negative binomial distributions as described in (Love et al. 2014), to identify taxa for which there was a significant logarithmic fold change (LFC) in abundance between groups. In addition, random Forest classification was used to understand feature importance of the bacterial DNA contamination originating from laboratory reagents and sample handling, as well as biases occurring during PCR amplification and sequencing have often been reported to distort the results on ASV data showed that coral samples clustered according to host species and treatment identify the ASVs for which the relative abundance significantly differed between A. tenuis and P. 508 daedalea (Figure 8 ). ASVs belonging to Alteromonadaceae (two different Alteromonas ASVs)
were found significantly more abundant in A. tenuis for both control and inoculated corals.

were significantly more abundant in inoculated A. tenuis compared to inoculated P. daedalea. In the 512 control treatments, Vibrionaceae (three Vibrio ASVs including ASV7) were more abundant in A. composition of the microbiome. At the sampling time point, bacterial communities of the two coral host species cultured in the same aquaria since the early recruit stage differed in terms of α-diversity 541 (bacterial communities in P. daedalea were richer than those in A. tenuis, Figure 2 ), β-diversity 542 (there was more variability across samples in A. tenuis than in P. daedalea, Figure 3) , and in the 543 relative abundance ( Figure 7 ) and presence/absence of particular bacterial taxa (Supplementary 544 Figure S8 ). In addition to harboring distinct bacterial communities, the two corals responded 545 differently to the inoculations in that the degree of shift away from the bacterial community 546 harbored by the control recruits was larger in A. tenuis than in P. daedalea (Figure 3) . The Some of the ASVs corresponding to the inoculated bacterial strains were more significantly 566 abundant in the inoculated compared to the control coral recruits ( Figure 5 ). The two corals, A. 567 tenuis and P. daedalea, may exhibit specific preferences for certain bacterial taxa and possess 568 different selection mechanisms to shape their bacterial communities. Potential probiotics for corals 569 might therefore need to be tailored to particular bacterial species in order to achieve optimal uptake.
Interestingly, the same two ASVs significantly enriched in inoculated A. tenuis (ASV4 -

Paracoccus and ASV6 -Pseudovibrio) were also characterized by the highest LFC in P. daedalea 572 (Table 3 ). ASV4 and ASV6 both belong to class Alphaproteobacteria, which was the dominant 573 bacterial class in all coral recruits in this study, while the five other ASVs used in the inocula are with a thick tissue layer, which provides more shading to the in hospite algal symbionts and energy 578 reserves for the host (Loya et al. 2001; Putnam et al. 2017) . Such contrasting morphological and 579 physiological properties might create microhabitats suitable for different types of microbes and also 580 dictate requirements for specific microbial functions. It is therefore not surprising that A. tenuis and It is possible the young A. tenuis and P. daedalea had already acquired a subset of bacteria from the 587 water surrounding parental colonies following gamete release and/or from the water in which larvae 588 and recruits were reared. Despite being filtered with 0.4 µm pore-sized membranes, the flow-589 through water in the experimental system contained some bacteria (as shown by the 16S rRNA gene 590 sequences found in water samples). However, the water-associated microbial communities were considerably divergent from the coral microbiota ( Supplementary Figure S5) , which emphasizes the ability of corals to select certain bacteria from the environment. Alternatively, adult A. tenuis and P. 593 daedalea may have vertically transmitted some bacterial symbionts to their offspring prior to 5). Bacteria used in the inocula were also among the major ASVs driving the separation of bacterial 611 communities associated with control and inoculated recruits (Table 3) capacity for sustained bacteria-coral associations following inoculation needs to be studied beyond laboratory-controlled conditions to understand the impact of these fluctuating factors.

The application of probiotics to wild corals (or to captive corals aimed to be deployed to the field 683 for reef restoration) requires further research into the possibility of scaling up such efforts. While 684 industrial infrastructures to produce cultured bacterial consortia already exist, the latter need to be 685 suitably delivered to corals. Inocula could be prepared by encapsulating bacteria into microscopic 686 feed particles (Peixoto et al. 2017) . Alternatively, probiotic bacteria could be administered through 687 a heterotrophic food source such as the brine shrimp Artemia, which has already proven successful 688 in spiny lobster larvae (Goulden et al. 2012) . As the delivery of probiotics to entire reef systems 689 could be unmanageable due to their large size as compared to available resources, efforts could be 690 prioritized to most vulnerable or ecologically relevant sites.

Importantly, potential environmental impacts should also be strictly evaluated. It is indeed argued 693 that coral reef ecosystems might be inadvertently harmed through manipulations that we cannot This study involved the co-culturing of two taxonomically divergent coral species and inoculating 710 them with a bacterial cocktail generated in the laboratory. Despite sharing the same environment 711 since a very early life stage, A. tenuis and P. daedalea recruits had distinct bacterial communities at 712 the time of sampling, which exhibited different responses to the inocula. In the absence of 713 confounding factors such as environmental parameters and algal symbiont type, our findings As the microbiomes of A. tenuis and P. daedalea changed in response to the inoculum, the bacteria present in the cocktail were identified as the ones driving the main differences between inoculated 717 and control corals. The bacterial pool surrounding these young recruits therefore also influenced 718 their microbiomes. The long-term maintenance and stability of inoculated bacteria in corals still 719 need to be characterized. By demonstrating the feasibility to manipulate the coral microbiome in a laboratory setting, our results provide hope for the application of probiotics in coral reef conservation and restoration.

FIGREF0.text: suggested in 2009 (Teplitski and Ritchie 2009), the field is still in its infancy but some early 127 promising results have been obtained. Fragments of the coral Mussismilia hartii were inoculated 128 with a bacterial consortium able to degrade water-soluble oil fractions, which reduced the negative 129 impact of a simulated oil spill on the experimental corals (dos Santos et al. 2015). In another 130 laboratory experiment, bacterial strains were selected for putatively beneficial traits including 131 nutrient cycling, antioxidative capacities, and antagonistic activities against pathogens (Rosado et 132 al. 2018). Inoculation of Pocillopora damicornis nubbins with the resulting consortium was able to 133 partially mitigate coral bleaching and alleviate pathogenic infection (Rosado et al. 2018). Thus, 134 coral bacterial community composition seems to be flexible to some extent and adjustable to benefit 135 the host. Finally, a single exposure of coral larvae to the mucus-associated microbes of four 136 different coral species resulted in divergent prokaryotic communities after four months of rearing in 137 filter-sterilized seawater (Damjanovic et al. 2017). Even though the initial inoculum composition 138 was not characterized, this experiment showed that coral-associated microbiomes could be 139 influenced to develop in distinct directions following microbial dosing. Early coral life stages may 140 be particularly suitable for targeted microbial inoculation, as the microbial composition and cell 141 density in the surrounding environment strongly influences the microbiome acquired by juvenile 142 corals

FIGREF1.text: examine whether different hosts are a determinant of the microbial community development. Coral 149 recruits of two taxonomically divergent species, Acropora tenuis and Platygyra daedalea, were co-150 cultured in the same aquaria and simultaneously exposed to a cocktail composed of pure bacterial 151 cultures. Metabarcoding of the 16S rRNA gene was used to assess the bacterial communities of the 152 coral recruits following repeated inoculations. While undefined host factors were shown to play a 153 role in the composition of coral recruit-associated bacterial communities, inoculated corals of both 154 species were significantly enriched for some of the taxa that comprised the inoculum compared to 155 non-inoculated control corals.

The 265 C. goreaui pure culture was obtained from the AIMS Symbiont Culture Facility. The algal cells had 266 been grown in Corning cell culture flasks at 27°C using a photoperiod of 14 h: 10 h light to dark 267 illumination cycle and 60 µmol•m -2 •s -1 . Cells were maintained in 0.2 µm FSW and Daigo's IMK 268 sterile culture medium for marine microalgae (Nihon Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd). This 269 Symbiodiniaceae species was chosen because it commonly associates with A. tenuis on the GBR 270 (LaJeunesse et al. 2004; van Oppen et al. 2005). While P. daedalea more often hosts a different 271 species of Symbiodiniaceae in the wild (formerly known as type C3) (Fisher et al. 2011), it also 272

FIGREF7.text: pipeline version 2017.10 (Caporaso et al. 2010; QIIME 2 Development Team 2017a). 332 Plugin demux (QIIME 2 Development Team 2017b) was used to visualize interactive quality plots 333 and check read quality. Plugin DADA2 (Callahan et al. 2016) was subsequently applied to remove 334 primers, truncate poor-quality bases based on the interactive plots, dereplicate, identify chimeras 335 and to merge paired-end reads. Commands included in the plugin feature-table (McDonald et al. 336 2012) enabled generation of summary statistics of sequences associated with the samples. For 16S 337 rRNA gene sequences, a Naïve Bayes Classifier was trained with the feature-classifier plugin 338 (QIIME 2 Development Team 2017d) using the 16S rRNA gene database at 99% similarity of the 339 SILVA 128 QIIME release (Quast et al. 2013) and based on the 784F/1061R primer pair. A 340 phylogenetic tree for further downstream analyses was created with the plugins alignment (Katoh 341 and Standley 2013) and phylogeny (Price et al. 2010). Finally, the taxa plugin (QIIME 2 342 Development Team 2017c) allowed to filter mitochondria and chloroplast sequences, as well as to 343 visualize taxonomic bar plots and generate tables with absolute read counts of all taxa for each 344 sample. For ITS2 sequences, taxonomic assignment was performed using the Arif et al. (Arif et al.

For example, members of the 517 families Hahellaceae (all belonging to the genus Endozoicomonas), Comamonadaceae, daedalea and absent from A. tenuis. report that coral-associated bacterial communities depend on environmental 529 factors and geographical location (Littman et al. 2009b; Lee et al. 2012; Pantos et al. 2015; Hester 530 et al. 2016), other reports indicate that corals harbor species-specific bacterial assemblages (Rohwer 531 et al. 2002; Rohwer and Kelley 2004; Bourne et al. 2008; Littman et al. 2009b; Tremblay et al. 532 2010; Apprill et al. 2012; Morrow et al. 2012; Ainsworth et al. 2015; Zhang et al. 2015; Chu and 533 Vollmer 2016). The observed differences in bacterial communities retrieved from corals versus 534 those from the surrounding water column are compelling evidence that coral-bacteria associations 535 are non-random and subject to selective mechanisms (Sunagawa et al. 2010; Sweet et al. 2010).

FIGREF11.text: Emerging data indicate both environmental and host factors are drivers of coral-associated 537 microbial community composition(Kvennefors et al. 2010; Kelly et al. 2014; Zhang et al. 2015;

FIGREF12.text: intrinsically higher microbial diversity in P. daedalea might have buffered the perturbation 548 introduced by the inocula, as empirical studies and mathematical models support the notion that 549 diverse ecosystems are more resistant to invasion than systems with lower diversity (Levine and550 D'Antonio 1999). The bacterial profiles of control A. tenuis and P. daedalea recruits are challenging 551 to compare with already published data. Previous studies on A. tenuis also report dominance of 552 Alpha-and Gammaproteobacteria (Supplementary Figure S7), but with variable proportions 553 (Littman et al. 2009b; Ceh et al. 2011). Only limited information exists on prokaryotic communities 554 associated with P. daedalea; one study focused on culturable Actinobacteria (Mahmoud and 555 Kalendar 2016), while another work reported a P. daedalea sample with a high abundance of 556 Alpha-and Gammaproteobacteria, mostly represented by Endozoicomonas (Liang et al. 2017). 557 Different species of adult corals have been reported to maintain distinct microbiomes when reared 558 in identical environments (Sweet et al. 2013), and our study shows that host factors already play a 559 role from early ontogeny. Importantly, our data were not confounded by the Symbiodiniaceae 560 species, which can influence bacterial community composition in young corals (Littman et al. 561 2009a), as both species were inoculated with the same monoclonal C. goreaui culture. 562 563 A. tenuis and P. daedalea recruits responded differently to the inocula 564 565

FIGREF13.text: . daedalea established associations with different microbial communities over the course of this 582 experiment. Field surveys have reported that branching and massive corals naturally tend to 583 associate with distinct bacterial communities, with higher α-diversities generally observed in 584 massive species (Liang et al. 2017).585 586

FIGREF14.text: . Effective inoculations were 612 thus not precluded by using bacteria isolated from non-coral organisms, which demonstrates a 613 degree of flexibility in the coral microbiome. Altogether, this study supports the proof-of-concept 614 for the feasibility of manipulating coral-associated prokaryotes (dos Santos et al. 2015; Rosado et insights into the efficacy of probiotics for coral reef restoration and conservation, 620 future research should target several aspects not covered in the present study. First, an optimal 621 inoculation regime should be developed through the determination of suitable inoculation frequency 622and bacterial cell density. In the present work, the seven inoculations at 10 5 -10 6 cells/mL arbitrarily 623 followed a 3-4-3-4 days pattern, as no standard procedure has yet been established. Alternative624 strategies have also yielded effective outcomes, such taking coral fragments out of the water and 625 inoculating them with one mL (10 7 cells/mL) twice five days apart (Rosado et al. 2018). 626 Nonetheless, systematic experiments are required to determine optimal inoculation protocols, by 627 using the same bacterial taxa, coral species and culture conditions while varying bacterial cell 628 density and/or frequency of inoculum administration. 629 630 This experiment was conducted over a short timescale (four weeks), which did not allow the long-631 term stability of coral-bacterial associations to be evaluated. It is not clear whether the dosed 632 bacteria would be retained over time, especially when no further bacteria are delivered. Also, shifts 633 in the coral microbiome following transfer between field and aquaria settings have been reported 634 (Pratte et al. 2015; Röthig et al. 2017), which could challenge the implementation of microbiome 635 manipulation strategies if the goal is to achieve long-term changes in the coral-associated 636 microbiome. The coral microbiome is dynamic (Mouchka et al. 2010; Sweet and Bulling 2017), 637 especially in early life stages (Littman et al. 2009a; Zhou et al. 2017; Epstein et al. 2019a). As 638 recruits develop and grow, the complex microbial communities associated with juveniles shift 639 towards less diverse adult microbiomes. Due to these natural processes, the impact of bacterial 640 inoculations during early life stages might diminish over time, but this needs to be tested. In 641 addition to life stage, numerous other biotic and abiotic factors may influence the coral microbiome, 642 such as abundance and changes in Symbiodiniaceae species, coral disease, and water parameters of 643 salinity, temperature, pH and nutrient levels (reviewed in (Hernandez-Agreda et al. 2016b)). The 644 P r o v i s i o n a l

FIGREF15.text: entirely predict or control(Sweet et al. 2017). For instance, disease agents such as pathogens or695 parasites could be transferred from captive systems to the natural environment and impact the 696 native fauna (Sweet et al. 2017). Moreover, potential probiotic bacteria (such as Vibrio) could be 697 converted into pathogens if they acquired the right virulence genes (Bruto et al. 2017). This would 698 be particularly problematic if probiotics are administered at large cell numbers. In general, an 699 overabundance of certain bacteria in the wild could have unintended effects on the ecosystem.

FIGREF16.text: Therefore, future research should focus on understanding the risk of probiotics before releasing701 microbes into open reefs (National Academies of Sciences Engineering and Medicine 2019). It has 702already been advocated that rigorous scientific trials and risk/benefit analyses should be carried out 703 prior to introducing any foreign microbial communities into the ocean(van Oppen et al. 2017).

FIGREF20.text: Overview of the experimental design. (A) Larvae from A. tenuis and P. daedalea were 1078 independently settled on plugs pre-conditioned with a microbial biofilm and CCA and subsequently 1079 sterilized. Six days post-settlement, recruits were counted and randomized across twelve 60 L tanks 1080 containing flow-through FSW. (B) On each inoculation day, bacterial pure cultures grown on MA 1081from the frozen stocks were suspended in FSW and adjusted to similar densities in order to prepare 1082 a fresh bacterial cocktail. Recruits from each 60 L tank were placed in containers filled with 1 L of 1083 static FSW. The bacterial cocktail was added to six containers using a serological pipette to inject 1084 10 mL of the suspension into the water directly above the recruits. The bacterial density in the 1085 inoculated containers was estimated at 10 5 -10 6 cells/mL. Recruits from the control treatments were 1086 handled in the same manner, except that FSW was added to the containers instead of the bacterial 1087 cocktail. After 6 h in static water, recruits were transferred back into the 60 L flow-through tanks.1088Two days following the last inoculation, all recruits were counted, sampled from the 60 L tanks1089 together with 1 L of surrounding water and snap-frozen for DNA extraction and 16S rRNA gene 1090 metabarcoding. (B) Representative pictures of A. 1096 tenuis (top) and P. daedalea recruits (bottom) at four weeks post-settlement. Rel ab = relative abundance. 1114 Representative output of the random Forest classification with 100 iterations to identify 1116 the most important predictor ASVs in A. tenuis (orange) and P. daedalea (blue). Each dot represents one ASV (including ASVs 4, 6, and 7 from the inocula), 1126 here identified at the genus level when possible. Positive values represent ASVs proportionally 1127 more abundant in P. daedalea, while negative values are ASVs proportionally more abundant in A. 1128 tenuis.

A test for homogeneity of multivariate dispersions (Anderson 2006) was used to check for homogeneity of variances and pairwise comparisons were performed between groups using a single-step (Scheffé 1953) and the Benjamin and Hochberg corrections for multiple testing
